title: Mutiny In The Mist
opening: Your house must help the Knights of Seiros suppress Lord Lonato's rebellion at Castle Gaspard. Though you are told not to expect combat, the deep fog at Magdred Way sets you ill at ease...

intro.speaker: Hubert
intro.line: No matter how powerful our enemies may be, there is no need to worry so long as we're with Catherine, the mighty wielder of Thunderbrand.

intro.speaker: Byleth
intro.line: Thunderbrand?

intro.speaker: Byleth
intro.line: What are you talking about?

intro.speaker: Catherine
intro.line: You mean you don't know? My weapon is called Thunderbrand. It's one of the Hero's Relics. A long, long time ago, the goddess bestowed divine weapons upon 10 heroes, which were passed down to their descendants. It's an honor to wield, but I'm afraid there won't be any chance for that today. Our mission is to help clean up the aftermath, not to fight.

intro.speaker: Hubert
intro.line: One must wonder why Lord Lonato would incite such a reckless rebellion.

intro.speaker: Catherine
intro.line: It all goes back to the Tragedy of Duscur...

intro.speaker: Byleth
intro.line: I've heard of it.

intro.speaker: Edelgard
intro.line: I remember that day well. No one saw it coming.

intro.speaker: Byleth
intro.line: I don't know much about it.

intro.speaker: Edelgard
intro.line: Roughly four years ago, the king of Faerghus was murdered by the people of Duscur. I believe that about sums it up, correct?

intro.speaker: Catherine
intro.line: To put it simply, yes. But there's more to that story. They had accomplices within the Kingdom as well. Lord Lonato's son, Christophe, was one of them, and so he was handed over to the church for execution.

intro.speaker: Byleth
intro.line: The church executes criminals?

intro.speaker: Catherine
intro.line: Speaking from the church's perspective, we simply passed judgement according to our doctrine in place of the Kingdom, which was in complete chaos.

intro.speaker: Byleth
intro.line: Why was the king targeted?

intro.speaker: Catherine
intro.line: King Lambert was attempting a major political reform. Needless to say, he had many enemies.

intro.speaker: Dimitri
intro.line: I have to say... It's a real honor to accompany such a brave and distinguished knight. None other than Catherine, wielder of Thunderbrand!

intro.speaker: Byleth
intro.line: Thunderbrand?

intro.speaker: Catherine
intro.line: You mean you don't know? My weapon is called Thunderbrand. It's one of the Hero's Relics. A long, long time ago, the goddess bestowed divine weapons upon 10 heroes, which were passed down to their descendants. It's an honor to wield, but I'm afraid there won't be any chance for that today. Our mission is to help clean up the aftermath, not to fight.

intro.speaker: Ashe
intro.line: Why would Lonato incite such a reckless rebellion?

intro.speaker: Catherine
intro.line: You should know more about that than any of us, Ashe.

intro.speaker: Ashe
intro.line: Well, I don't. Lonato never mentioned anything of the like to me.

intro.speaker: Dimitri
intro.line: He probably didn't want you getting caught up in his own personal vendetta.

intro.speaker: Byleth
intro.line: Is Ashe related to Lord Lonato?

intro.speaker: Ashe
intro.line: I'm Lonato's adopted son. He raised me as though I were his own blood. He was always so kind. I don't understand... I guess it has to do with Christophe.

intro.speaker: Byleth
intro.line: What vendetta?

intro.speaker: Catherine
intro.line: How much do you know about the Tragedy of Duscur, Professor?

intro.speaker: Byleth
intro.line: I've heard of it.

intro.speaker: Byleth
intro.line: I don't know much about it.

intro.speaker: Catherine
intro.line: It's when the king of the Holy Kingdom of Faerghus was...was murdered by the people of Duscur. It happened about four years ago...

intro.speaker: Dimitri
intro.line: It's OK, Catherine. Please, go on.

intro.speaker: Catherine
intro.line: Right. Well, Lord Lonato's son, Christophe, was accused of being involved in that whole awful affair. He was executed by the church.

intro.speaker: Byleth
intro.line: The church executes prisoners?

intro.speaker: Catherine
intro.line: Speaking from the church's perspective, we simply passed judgement according to our doctrine in place of the Kingdom, which was in complete chaos.

intro.speaker: Byleth
intro.line: Why was the king targeted?

intro.speaker: Catherine
intro.line: King Lambert was attempting a major political reform. Needless to say, he had many enemies.

intro.speaker: Claude
intro.line: It really is an honor to accompany Catherine, wielder of Thunderbrand. I hear you're intimidating enough to silence the howling winds!

intro.speaker: Byleth
intro.line: Thunderbrand?

intro.speaker: Catherine
intro.line: You mean you don't know? My weapon is called Thunderbrand. It's one of the Hero's Relics. A long, long time ago, the goddess bestowed divine weapons upon 10 heroes, which were passed down to their descendants. It's an honor to wield, but I'm afraid there won't be any chance for that today. Our mission is to help clean up the aftermath, not to fight.

intro.speaker: Claude
intro.line: Why would Lonato incite such a reckless rebellion? He had to have known he had no chance of winning.

intro.speaker: Catherine
intro.line: It all goes back to the Tragedy of Duscur...

intro.speaker: Byleth
intro.line: I've heard of it.

intro.speaker: Byleth
intro.line: I don't know much about it.

intro.speaker: Claude
intro.line: You must be joking. Where have you been traveling that news of it didn't reach you?

intro.speaker: Claude
intro.line: It happened about four years ago. The king of the Holy Kingdom of Faerghus was murdered by the people of Duscur. That about covers it, right?

intro.speaker: Catherine
intro.line: To put it simply, yes. But there's more to that story. They had accomplices within the Kingdom as well. Lord Lonato's son, Christophe, was one of them, and so he was handed over to the church for execution.

intro.speaker: Byleth
intro.line: The church executes criminals?

intro.speaker: Catherine
intro.line: Speaking from the church's perspective, we simply passed judgement according to our doctrine in place of the Kingdom, which was in complete chaos.

intro.speaker: Byleth
intro.line: Why was the king targeted?

intro.speaker: Catherine
intro.line: King Lambert was attempting a major political reform. Needless to say, he had many enemies.

intro.speaker: Catherine
intro.line: Whatever the truth behind that incident may be, Lord Lonato has harbored resentment to the church ever since. Well... To be more specific, his grudge isn't only against the church. It's also against the one who turned Christophe over to them...

intro.speaker: Church Soldier
intro.line: Report! The enemy is approaching! They can't be avoided. Their numbers are far greatly than we predicted. They used the fog to slip past the knights' perimeter!

intro.speaker: Catherine
intro.line: It looks like our mission just changed, Professor. Everyone, prepare for battle!

conversation.speaker: Sothis
conversation.line: You have spent quite some time in here, engaging in such idle chatter. Do you not know that we do not have a moment left to waste?

conversation.speaker: Byleth
conversation.line: I had forgotten.

conversation.speaker: Sothis
conversation.line: Forgotten? I don't believe that is the truth. No, it is more likely you were dreaming the whole day away. You must try harder from now on.

conversation.speaker: Byleth
conversation.line: I should have listened more intently.

conversation.speaker: Sothis
conversation.line: You must try harder from now on.

conversation.speaker: Edelgard
conversation.line: Even within the Knights of Seiros, Catherine is the strongest. By a large margin from what I've gathered. Why not seek her out as a sparring partner, professor?

conversation.speaker: Edelgard
conversation.line: Lord Lonato must know that his efforts are futile...yet he can't help but fight. If I were in that situation, I would do whatever it took to ensure victory. You can count on that.

conversation.speaker: Dimitri
conversation.line: Doubtless, there are times when one must take up their blade, even if there's no chance of winning. But this... It's downright senseless. Lord Lonato knows better. If he had enough allies to back his rebellion, it would be a different matter...

conversation.speaker: Byleth
conversation.line: Allies?

conversation.speaker: Byleth
conversation.line: How so?

conversation.speaker: Dimitri
conversation.line: Ah, my apologies. I was just thinking aloud. This whole situation is a bit too strange for my liking. Even with the necessary preparations in place, there is always a chance that something unexpected will occur. Please be ready for anything, Professor.

conversation.speaker: Dimitri
conversation.line: After Faerghus lost its king, there were many rebellions. It is likely Lord Lonato's provocations are related. How frustrating that I am too young to take the throne. Rendered powerless by age... If the throne is vacant much longer, the Kingdom will fall to ruin!

conversation.speaker: Claude
conversation.line: First that bandit business, and now a noble rebellion? Are we ever gonna do anything but find and subdue people? Well, if we're just going to tie up loose ends, at least it'll be pretty safe. I don't mind stretching my legs for this one. And if Catherine's going, too, there's a good chance we'll get a look at her Relic in action.

conversation.speaker: Claude
conversation.line: Hey, Teach. There's some minor noble rebelling in Faerghus, right? He has no chance of winning. I wonder what he hopes to achieve... Huh? Are you going along to help? Sounds like an easy victory, but good luck out there.

conversation.speaker: Hubert
conversation.line: Something about this situation doesn't feel right. Why would a minor lord raise an army against a foe he cannot possibly hope to defeat?

conversation.speaker: Ferdinand
conversation.line: My central duty as a noble is to protect the commonfolk. I abhor those like Lord Lonato, who deliberately shatter the peace. Utterly disgraceful.

conversation.speaker: Byleth
conversation.line: He must have his reasons.

conversation.speaker: Byleth
conversation.line: I hope no one is hurt.

conversation.speaker: Ferdinand
conversation.line: You have a kind soul, Professor. Now I feel a little sheepish for showing anger and not empathy. I apologize for my impetuousness.

conversation.speaker: Ferdinand
conversation.line: I heard about your class's assignment, by the way. Good luck subduing those treasonous nobles!

conversation.speaker: Linhardt
conversation.line: Professor, I feel I must speak to you about Caspar's eating habits. I've never seen the likes of it. He inhales entire plates of food in mere seconds.

conversation.speaker: Byleth
conversation.line: Sounds unhealthy.

conversation.speaker: Linhardt
conversation.line: Hence my mentioning it to you. Good luck with him.

conversation.speaker: Byleth
conversation.line: He must have a healthy appetite.

conversation.speaker: Linhardt
conversation.line: If that is a polite way of calling him a goat, I'm inclined to agree.

conversation.speaker: Caspar
conversation.line: Today's meal was delicious! Linhardt keeps bothering me about eating too fast. Says I'm gonna choke or something.

conversation.speaker: Byleth
conversation.line: It's not safe to each so quickly.

conversation.speaker: Caspar
conversation.line: You're really gonna agree with that guy? Why is no one here on my side?

conversation.speaker: Byleth
conversation.line: When you're busy there's no alternative.

conversation.speaker: Caspar
conversation.line: Absolutely! I knew you'd see things my way.

conversation.speaker: Bernadetta
conversation.line: ♪Hm hm-hm hm-hm... ♪ H-huh?! Um, is someone there? What do you want?

conversation.speaker: Dorothea
conversation.line: Professor, about this month's assignment... Raising an army against the church? Really? Though it looks like we won't be fighting, it's still quite unsettling. My understanding is that it will all be subdued rather quickly.

conversation.speaker: Dorothea
conversation.line: Are you going to fight alongside the Knights of Seiros? Hmm... Let me know if you meet anyone I might be interested in, OK?

conversation.speaker: Petra
conversation.line: The plants of Fódlan are different ones than in Brigid. And people here are unknowing of the spirits who watch over the earth and bless it. Only the goddess is known. Is that factual?

conversation.speaker: Petra
conversation.line: This flower is one that is eating insects. Is that factual too? I am wondering who watches over the plants in Fódlan...

conversation.speaker: Dedue
conversation.line: His Highness is strong. But on the front lines, anything can happen. Losing him would be devastating for Faerghus. I hope the church understands that.

conversation.speaker: Dedue
conversation.line: Best be on your guard.

conversation.speaker: Felix
conversation.line: Catherine, hm? Her skill is impressive, I'll admit. So is her sword. But I think she's hiding something. Nobody knows anything about her past. You should spar with her. She's strong. Stronger than you are, I'd bet.

conversation.speaker: Ashe
conversation.line: Ngh... Please, Professor, there must be some mistake. Lonato would never raise arms against the church. At least, he never said anything to me about it.

conversation.speaker: Ashe
conversation.line: What's going to happen to Lonato? If he's killed, I... I don't know how I'll live with that.

conversation.speaker: Sylvain
conversation.line: Professor, have you seen Felix around? I swear, as soon as you take your eyes off him–poof–he's gone.

conversation.speaker: Byleth
conversation.line: I saw him at the training ground.

conversation.speaker: Sylvain
conversation.line: Ah, of course he's there. Sorry for bothering you, Professor. Thanks!

conversation.speaker: Byleth
conversation.line: I saw him at the dining hall.

conversation.speaker: Sylvain
conversation.line: Ah, right, it is meal time. Sorry for bothering you, Professor. Thanks!

conversation.speaker: Sylvain
conversation.line: Don't you love looking after horses? I do. They repay your absolute love and trust with the same. I wish girls were so easy to deal with...

conversation.speaker: Mercedes
conversation.line: I've heard whispers about Lord Lonato. They say he is a very kind and gentle lord. Why would such a kind man suddenly raise an army? Oh, Professor. You were working late last night, weren't you? You shouldn't overdo it. A ghost might rise up from the well to get you if you stay you too late! Or so I'm told.

conversation.speaker: Annette
conversation.line: We're going on a mission with the knights, right? I wonder if... Oh... Sorry! It's nothing. I was just wondering if someone I've been searching for might be among them.

conversation.speaker: Byleth
conversation.line: You're looking for a knight?

conversation.speaker: Annette
conversation.line: Yes. Well...maybe? If he's here, he's probably a knight. Though it's also possible he became a monk...

conversation.speaker: Byleth
conversation.line: I hope you find whomever you're looking for.

conversation.speaker: Annette
conversation.line: Thank you. I'm definitely going to find him one of these days!

conversation.speaker: Annette
conversation.line: To be honest, I've felt a bit lost here at the monastery. At a loss for what to do. Thankfully, a sweet young girl reached out and offered help. I believe she's Seteth's little sister.

conversation.speaker: Ingrid
conversation.line: Why does His Highness take the side of the people of Duscur? I just don't understand it. Only four years ago, they murdered our king and slaughtered the soldiers and knights who were with him, all of whom were innocent. Even if he can forgive them, I can't–not ever. What they've done is against all codes of honor and ethics.

conversation.speaker: Ingrid
conversation.line: We are truly blessed with how fertile the monastery grounds are. Every day, there's something new to harvest!

conversation.speaker: Lorenz
conversation.line: It's a noble's duty to protect the commonfolk, not to endanger them by rallying armies in such a feckless and improper manner. Abuse of that kind is no better than slavery. A proper noble must guard the people from such a fate, wouldn't you say?

conversation.speaker: Byleth
conversation.line: I agree.

conversation.speaker: Lorenz
conversation.line: Precisely why true nobility is well respected.

conversation.speaker: Byleth
conversation.line: We don't know all the details yet.

conversation.speaker: Lorenz
conversation.line: There can be no legitimate cause for a noble to abandon that basic obligation. Let us put an end to this quickly.

conversation.speaker: Raphael
conversation.line: Hey, Professor! Do you happen to have any food on you? I'm starving! No matter how much I eat before I train, I'm always so hungry after. My muscles must be going through a growth spurt!

conversation.speaker: Ignatz
conversation.line: This place has so many breathtaking works of art. I feel like I'm living in a museum. Each piece can teach us about styles and techniques from a thousand years ago!

conversation.speaker: Byleth
conversation.line: Do you know a lot about art?

conversation.speaker: Ignatz
conversation.line: I'm from a family of merchants, so I've been able to see a lot of art, but I won't pretend to be an expert.

conversation.speaker: Byleth
conversation.line: Do you like art?

conversation.speaker: Ignatz
conversation.line: Oh yes, very much. I'm from a family of merchants, so I've been able to see a lot of art.

conversation.speaker: Lysithea
conversation.line: Ah, Professor. It would seem that a minor lord in Faerghus is raising an army… This poses a threat, obviously. But not one for the Kingdom—for the church. I mean, Faerghus doesn’t even have a king at present. There’s something…unsettling about this army. You had better ensure we’re fully prepared.

conversation.speaker: Lysithea
conversation.line: The monastery grounds are far too spread out. Feels like it takes hours to get from one area to another. And, no, that's not because I'm getting lost. I'm a fully capable, mature person! Who never gets lost.

conversation.speaker: Marianne
conversation.line: Oh. Hello, Professor... Um. Was there something you needed?

conversation.speaker: Byleth
conversation.line: I came to see the horses.

conversation.speaker: Marianne
conversation.line: Oh! You like horses? I like them too. They're such kind creatures.

conversation.speaker: Byleth
conversation.line: I'm just looking around.

conversation.speaker: Marianne
conversation.line: I see. I won't bother you, then...

conversation.speaker: Hilda
conversation.line: Professor, your clothes are a bit dirty. If you don't pay attention to your hygiene, the girls won't like you! I hate when my clothes get dirty. That's one of the many reasons I find it best to train as little as possible.

conversation.speaker: Hilda
conversation.line: Professor, your clothes are a bit dirty. I'd have expected you to be more careful, seeing as how you're a professor and all. I hate when my clothes get dirty. That's one of the many reasons I find it best to train as little as possible.

conversation.speaker: Leonie
conversation.line: I'm studying here so I can be the best there is, just like Captain Jeralt. Do you think I've got it in me to be a top tier mercenary, Professor?

conversation.speaker: Byleth
conversation.line: That depends on how hard you work.

conversation.speaker: Leonie
conversation.line: I'm going to work a lot harder than all the fancy nobles around here, I can tell you that.

conversation.speaker: Byleth
conversation.line: You really want to bring the money in, huh?

conversation.speaker: Leonie
conversation.line: I do! Though, it's about so much more than being rich. It's about honor.

conversation.speaker: Rhea
conversation.line: Pointing a sword at the Holy Church of Seiros is akin to pointing a sword at the goddess herself. Meting out appropriate punishments to the sinful... It is a sacred duty with which we have been entrusted. As a member of the church yourself, I hope that you will take that to heart.

conversation.speaker: Seteth
conversation.line: If you have a moment, I would like to have a word. It has been brought to my attention that certain individuals have been making advances towards Flayn. You wouldn't happen to know anything about that, would you?

conversation.speaker: Byleth
conversation.line: Not at all.

conversation.speaker: Byleth
conversation.line: Actually...

conversation.speaker: Seteth
conversation.line: If you do see anyone getting too close with Flayn, please, inform me of it at once.

conversation.speaker: Flayn
conversation.line: If the flowers within the greenhouse are removed, they will soon wilt and whither... Is that not so, Professor? I feel I can empathize with them... The flowers. Flowers that thrive–despite their environment–are truly inspiring, are they not?

conversation.speaker: Alois
conversation.line: Past here is the Holy Mausoleum, where the saints of the Church of Seiros slumber. Sorry, but only a select few members of the church are allowed entry. It's open to the public on only one day of the year, for the Goddess's Rite of Rebirth.

conversation.speaker: Catherine
conversation.line: Here to train? You really are as hardworking as they say.

conversation.speaker: Byleth
conversation.line: That's an overstatement. I'm just me.

conversation.speaker: Catherine
conversation.line: Spoken like a true hard worker.

conversation.speaker: Byleth
conversation.line: That's right. I'm a force of nature.

conversation.speaker: Catherine
conversation.line: Huh. Maybe the gossip's wrong. Hardworking people usually don't like to make a big fuss about it.

conversation.speaker: Jeritza
conversation.line: What? I desired fresh air.

conversation.speaker: Byleth
conversation.line: That's not like you.

conversation.speaker: Jeritza
conversation.line: True...

conversation.speaker: Byleth
conversation.line: The wind feels nice.

conversation.speaker: Jeritza
conversation.line: Hmph.

conversation.speaker: Jeralt
conversation.line: Castle Gaspard, eh? I've been there once before. Many years ago... It was by request of the son of that family... Christophe, I think it was.

conversation.speaker: Hanneman
conversation.line: I'm sorry, but I must vent to someone, Professor. You're familiar with Manuela's slovenly behavior, yes? That woman! She borrowed a book last week and returned it with stains of unknown origin on the cover, and several pages either folded or torn. Just now, she dropped a sandwich on the floor, picked it up and kept eating. When she saw my shock, she said simply, "Three second rule." Ugh!

conversation.speaker: Manuela
conversation.line: Did you hear? There's news of someone in the Kingdom raising an army. The Kingdom, the Empire, the Alliance... They do love a good war, don't they? Spilling the blood of young men and women...and for what? Just to enjoy the horror of it?

conversation.speaker: Tomas
conversation.line: Professor, I heard that you may battle alongside Catherine. Even among the knights, she is something special⁠—a holy knight who is able to wield a Hero's Relic. Still...she can be a mite difficult.

conversation.speaker: Anna
conversation.line: Hey, Professor. How's it going? Making lots of coin? I'd love to catch up, but I'm super busy right now. Working. For money. You understand.

conversation.speaker: Gatekeeper
conversation.line: Greetings, Professor! Nothing to report! Have you talked with Catherine yet? If the knights are the cream of the crop, she's the cream of the cream. Oh, and that Relic of hers! I hear it's nothing short of amazing.

conversation.speaker: Knight Of Seiros
conversation.line: Since we're heading to Castle Gaspard, that means we'll be passing through Magdred Way. The road is well known for its beautiful surroundings. Depending on the time of year, it can be incredibly foggy, though. When it's like that you can't enjoy the lovely scenery... Lucky for us, it shouldn't be too foggy while we're there. Not that we'll have time for sightseeing anyway.

conversation.speaker: Knight Of Seiros
conversation.line: I hear that Lord Lonato served the king of Faerghus's older brother when he was younger. Or something like that. He already had status and prestige, so why raise a rebellion? Eh, I guess it's none of my business.

conversation.speaker: Knight Of Seiros
conversation.line: Catherine has invited me to train with her. How much do you think I should train before I'm ready to train with someone that strong?

conversation.speaker: Monk
conversation.line: Lord Lonato... He used to stay at the monastery rather frequently. He was such as pious man. A true believer... Such a terrible shame. I wonder what changed him...

conversation.speaker: Monk
conversation.line: Next month is when a very important ceremony will be taking place at the monastery. Pilgrims from all corners of Fódlan have already started to gather in anticipation. I pray that you are able to nip this trouble in the bud as soon as possible.

conversation.speaker: Shifty Merchant
conversation.line: Things we can't obtain here are likely obtainable by way of the underground. Are you unfamiliar with Garreg Mach's underground? The place is an absolute paradise for those who can't stay above ground.

conversation.speaker: Monk
conversation.line: Those Abyssian idiots. All they ever do is cause trouble. We'd best purge the entire underbelly of Garreg Mach.

battle.speaker: Lonato
battle.line: The fog has cleared. There's nothing left to hide you or the filthy Central Church from the judgement of the goddess!

battle.speaker: Edelgard
battle.line: I'm sorry, but I don't believe Lord Lonato has the strength to carry on.

battle.speaker: Dimitri
battle.line: I am sorry... But did you really think you would get away with this?

battle.speaker: Claude
battle.line: The nobles start the war, but it's the commoners who spill their blood first...

boss.speaker: Lonato
boss.line: You have been deceived by that witch... I will show you the truth!

boss.speaker: Lonato
boss.line: You! I will be the one to kill you, no other!

boss.speaker: Catherine
boss.line: You have lost all sense of justice.  You want to fight me? So be it. I'll send you to meet your goddess.

boss.speaker: Lonato
boss.line: Stand down, Ashe. I must destroy these evil-doers by any means necessary!

boss.speaker: Ashe
boss.line: Please surrender, Lonato! Whatever your reason for doing this, we can still talk it out!

boss.speaker: Lonato
boss.line: Rhea is an infidel who has deceived the people and desecrated the goddess! We have virtue and the goddess herself on our side!

boss.speaker: Ashe
boss.line: Even if all that's true, dragging the townsfolk into it like this isn't right!

boss.speaker: Lonato
boss.line: Enough. If that is how you feel, prepare yourself! I'm putting an end to this!

boss.speaker: Lonato
boss.line: I apologize, Your Highness. It is regrettable that we should cross swords like this.

boss.speaker: Dimitri
boss.line: Lonato, I sympathize with your position. I really do. I have no wish to kill you, but I am afraid you have left me no choice. Please...forgive me.

boss.speaker: Lonato
boss.line: Your Highness... I cannot stop here. For my child, and for the people of Fódlan. If you will not stand aside, then I have no choice but to cut you down.

cutscene.speaker: Lonato
cutscene.line: It's you. Thunderstrike Cassandra! It was your wretched zealotry that killed my son!

cutscene.speaker: Catherine
cutscene.line: The only name I answer to is "Catherine". Prepare to taste the blade of one who serves the goddess. Now you face a Knight of Seiros!

end.speaker: Lonato
end.line: That vile woman... Christophe... Forgive me...

end.speaker: Ashe
end.line: Lonato, I...

end.speaker: Catherine
end.line: I never thought I'd see Lonato meet this fate.  Well done, everyone. Let's gather our troops and go.

end.speaker: Caspar
end.line: Damn it! It was all so pointless. I've never seen so many people utterly heartbroken...

end.speaker: Ferdinand
end.line: Forcing innocent citizens to risk their lives... That man was not a noble, but a monster.

end.speaker: Hubert
end.line: What could have pushed Lord Lonato to this point?

end.speaker: Edelgard
end.line: Everyone was a bit shaken by the militia fighting alongside our enemies.

end.speaker: Byleth
end.line: No use dwelling on it.

end.speaker: Byleth
end.line: That is the reality of battle.

end.speaker: Edelgard
end.line: If only everyone could face reality so unflinchingly. The commoners who allied themselves with Lord Lonato believed they were fighting for a just cause. It would be disrespectful to consider them simply victims when they died for what they believed in. Still, we have no choice but to eliminate those who cling to unreasonable ideas of justice. Even if our enemies are the gods themselves...we must never lose sight of our goal.

end.speaker: Byleth
end.line: That's taking it a bit far.

end.speaker: Edelgard
end.line: Is it? Such a day may come, whether you expect it or not. You should be ready.

end.speaker: Byleth
end.line: Agreed.

end.speaker: Edelgard
end.line: I'm surprised to hear you say that.

end.speaker: Edelgard
end.line: Really, I'm just like Lonato. I, too, will be the sort of ruler who's willing to risk the lives of my citizens in service of a higher cause. It's not possible to change the world without sacrifice. Dying for the greater good is not a death in vain.

end.speaker: Catherine
end.line: Professor... I'm afraid this incident is far more serious than anticipated.

end.speaker: Ashe
end.line: Why... Why did this happen? Lonato was always such a kind man... Everyone in the village was...was so nice to me. And I...I killed them. I killed them all! I had to, I know I had to... I know that! But still... What does that make me?

end.speaker: Dimitri
end.line: Please, don't beat yourself up, Ashe. We did what had to be done.

end.speaker: Ashe
end.line: I'm...I'm sorry. I shouldn't be bothering you. I'm...I'm going to check on the town. I hope my brother and sister are OK.

end.speaker: Dimitri
end.line: That...that was my first time killing civilians too... Those who I'm sworn to protect.

end.speaker: Byleth
end.line: It was a necessary sacrifice.

end.speaker: Byleth
end.line: That is the reality of war.

end.speaker: Dimitri
end.line: Are you insane?! Those weren't knights or soldiers, but fathers and sons! We...we shouldn't have killed them. We should have found another way... I...I'm sorry. It's not fair for me to blame you for the circumstance. I know that if we hadn't...done what we did, even more civilian lives would have been lost. At least, my mind understands that. But...my heart... Professor... Those in power, no matter the era, always claim they fight for a just cause. That they take life to protect it. But... Is it truly OK to take any life you please, all in service of some implacable "just cause"? Lord Lonato didn't take up arms out of a lust for power. He simply believed his cause to be just. Who's to say it wasn't? Maybe we didn't have to cut him down like that. Maybe we could have reached a mutual understanding...found a path of peace. I...I have to believe that. Perhaps the notion sounds laughable to you. Mere lip service to naive ideals. But I can't believe otherwise.

end.speaker: Catherine
end.line: Sorry to intrude, but this incident may be more serious than anticipated.

end.speaker: Claude
end.line: Nice work, Teach. Still...that fight left a foul taste in my mouth. That aside, did you see how Catherine fought?

end.speaker: Byleth
end.line: She's incredible.

end.speaker: Claude
end.line: Agreed. I thought the power of the Heroes' Relics must be exaggerated, but I was clearly wrong.

end.speaker: Byleth
end.line: I'm stronger.

end.speaker: Claude
end.line: Ha! I love the confidence, Teach. But you're no match for the Heroes' Relics. They're on a whole different level.

end.speaker: Claude
end.line: Makes you wonder about that legend...

end.speaker: Byleth
end.line: What legend?

end.speaker: Claude
end.line: Oh, it's nothing. Just the usual fanciful nonsense. An ancient Relic that once cut a mountain in half with a single swing. That's what they say, anyway. But as amazing as Thunderbrand is, I don't think it fits that description. Apparently, Relics can harness tremendous power for those with a compatible Crest. Though you can technically use one so long as you have any Crest at all. I dunno. Long story short, I'd like to try cutting a mountain in half someday.

end.speaker: Hilda
end.line: Ooh! Are you talking about Relics? You'll be able to wield one soon, Claude! I just know it! After all, you've already been selected as the next head of House Riegan!

end.speaker: Claude
end.line: Easy there, Hilda. I don't know how apt "soon" is. My grandfather is still unbearably healthy. Oh? Is this news to you, Teach? Yours truly was recently recognized as a legitimate child of House Riegan. They possess one of the Heroes' Relics too, though I've yet to see it.

end.speaker: Byleth
end.line: Just recently?

end.speaker: Claude
end.line: I officially joined House Riegan only last year. Before then, I lived with my father.

end.speaker: Byleth
end.line: You haven't seen it?

end.speaker: Claude
end.line: I was raised by my father. House Riegan is on my mother's side of the family.

end.speaker: Claude
end.line: When I learned that my mother was the daughter of an Alliance noble, I was so surprised I thought the whole world was pulling a fast one on me for a week.

end.speaker: Hilda
end.line: So that means your mother is Duke Riegan's daughter, right? Where is she now?

end.speaker: Claude
end.line: I can't say. My mother's currently living in a different world than the one she grew up in and has no desire to return home.

end.speaker: Hilda
end.line: Um, OK. You sure have a lot of secrets, don't you?

end.speaker: Claude
end.line: I'm just keeping a promise to my parents. Make of that whatever you will. In exchange for my so-called secrecy, I'm free to do as I please, which is why I decided to see what the other side of my family was like. That's how I found out about this strange Crest I bear...

end.speaker: Leonie
end.line: Professor, Claude. It sounds like the troops will be withdrawing soon. We should return as well.

end.speaker: Ignatz
end.line: We won. We should be celebrating. Instead, we're heading back with heavy hearts...

end.speaker: Claude
end.line: Whoa there! What's the matter? You look as sad as a kitten without any yarn. If we hadn't done what we did, the rebel army would have followed this road all the way to the monastery. And they would have crushed all the little villages along the way. We stopped that from happening. You should be proud.

end.speaker: Catherine
end.line: Sorry to intrude, but this incident may be more serious than anticipated.

end.speaker: Catherine
end.line: I found this on Lord Lonato. It's a note that mentions a plan to assassinate Lady Rhea. We can't tell who sent it, so the source is suspect, but the content is too disturbing to ignore. We must report this to Lady Rhea right away. I hope that it's nothing...

end.speaker: Rhea
end.line: I am glad to see that you have returned safely. The goddess is gracious with her divine protection. But it was not only her divine protection that shielded you, was it? You are just as skilled as I had hoped.

end.speaker: Byleth
end.line: My students deserve the praise.

end.speaker: Rhea
end.line: I am not so sure.

end.speaker: Byleth
end.line: I still have much to learn.

end.speaker: Rhea
end.line: There is no need for modesty.

end.speaker: Rhea
end.line: I heard some of the students were...hesitant about fighting militia. However, we must punish any sinner who may inflict harm upon believers, even if those sinners are civilians. I pray the students learned a valuable lesson about the fate that awaits all who are foolish enough to point their blades towards the heavens.

end.speaker: Seteth
end.line: Our real concern is what Catherine reported. The secret message that was in Lord Lonato's possession. It contained a deplorable plot to target the archbishop on the day of the Goddess's Rite of Rebirth. The plan seems unrealistic at best, but a threat is a threat. We must maintain constant vigilance. To that end, I would like for you and your students to help with security on the day of the ritual.

end.speaker: Byleth
end.line: You can count on us.

end.speaker: Rhea
end.line: That is most reassuring. You have my gratitude.

end.speaker: Byleth
end.line: We won't let her down.

end.speaker: Rhea
end.line: That is most reassuring. You have my gratitude.

end.speaker: Byleth
end.line: Won't that endanger the students?

end.speaker: Rhea
end.line: Even if they encounter an enemy whom they cannot best, they should be fine so long as they have you on their side.

end.speaker: Seteth
end.line: The Rite of Rebirth is of paramount importance. It is when the Church of Seiros and its believers unite to pray for the return of the goddess. The archbishop and I will be confined to the Goddess Tower once the ritual begins. Of course, the knights will be on high alert as well, but there aren't enough of them to keep watch on every corner of the monastery. It is far from ideal to be forced to mobilize students, but the gravity of this situation requires that we all bend to avoid breaking.

end.speaker: Rhea
end.line: While there is no need to fear for my safety, we cannot turn a blind eye to those who would blaspheme so heinously.

end.speaker: Seteth
end.line: With any luck, this will all be for naught. Still, be on your guard.
